course_description: This course focuses on feedback control mechanisms that living organisms implement at the molecular level to execute their functions, with emphasis on techniques to design novel systems with prescribed behaviors. Students will learn how biological functions can be understood and designed using notions from feedback control.
syllabus_content:
Course Meeting Times

Lectures: 2 sessions / week, 1.5 hours / session

Prerequisites

18.03 Differential Equations

Biology (GIR)
One of the following courses:

7.01SC Fundamentals of Biology

7.012 Introductory Biology

7.013 Introductory Biology

7.014 Introductory Biology

Description

This course focuses on feedback control mechanisms that living organisms implement at the molecular level to execute their functions, with emphasis on techniques to design novel systems with prescribed behaviors. Students will learn how biological functions can be understood and designed using notions from feedback control.

Objectives

By the end of the course, students will know these things:

How to construct mathematical models of a large range of molecular mechanisms.

How to use these models along with analysis and design tools from controls and dynamical systems to predict and engineer the dynamics of molecular networks.

Textbook

Del Vecchio, Domitilla, and Richard M. Murray.
Biomolecular Feedback Systems
. Princeton University Press, 2014. ISBN: 9780691161532. [Preview with

An Introduction to Systems Biology: Design Principles of Biological Circuits
. Chapman and Hall / CRC Press, 2006. ISBN: 9781584886426. [Preview with
Google Books

Systems Biology in Practice: Concepts, Implementation and Application
. Wiley Blackwell, 2005. ISBN: 9783527310784. [Preview with
Google Books
]

Molecular Biology of the Cell
. 4th ed. Garland Science, 2002. ISBN: 9780849371615.
